questions.text: A 7-year-old girl is brought to the physician by her mother because of a slightly itchy rash that first appeared 3 days ago. Her mother says she has also been complaining of headaches and achy muscles since yesterday evening. The girl went on a camping trip for school 10 days ago. She recalls being bitten several times by mosquitoes. She has a history of atopic dermatitis. She lives in Massachusetts with both parents and her 4-year-old sister. Her temperature is 39.0°C (102.2°F). Physical examination shows a 3-cm, nontender rash on her left upper torso. A photograph of the rash is shown. There are also multiple 5 to 8-mm erythematous papules over the lower legs and forearms. Treatment with which of the following agents is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Amoxicillin is a first-line treatment for Lyme disease in children. Doxycycline is an alternative treatment for short courses (< 21 days) in pediatric patients.

Amoxicillin is the treatment of choice for patients with Lyme disease who are pregnant or lactating. Doxycycline is relatively contraindicated in patients who are pregnant or lactating because of its adverse effects on growing bones and teeth.

B) INCORRECT:

Ceftriaxone is the drug of choice in disseminated Lyme disease, which generally does not occur until 3–10 weeks after a bite from an infected tick. Also, while this patient has signs of early localized Lyme disease (i.e., erythema migrans, flulike symptoms), she does not have evidence of disseminated Lyme disease (e.g., Lyme arthritis, Lyme carditis, or neuroborreliosis), which would be an indication for treatment with ceftriaxone.

C) INCORRECT:

Clotrimazole can be used topically for the treatment of tinea corporis. Because tinea corporis also manifests with a circular rash, it may appear similar to Lyme disease. However, in contrast to erythema migrans, the rash associated with tinea corporis is scaly, severely itchy, and has raised borders. Furthermore, symptoms such as headaches and achy muscles make a different diagnosis more likely.
Image Description:

Localization: typically the upper body and arms
Lesion: local, multiple, eczematous, pruritic, red lesions with marginal pustules and scaling
Diagnosis: tinea corporis

D) INCORRECT:

Penicillin G is used to treat early or late disseminated Lyme disease, not early localized Lyme disease. While this patient has signs of early localized Lyme disease (i.e., erythema migrans, flulike symptoms), she does not have evidence of disseminated Lyme disease (e.g., Lyme arthritis, Lyme carditis, or neuroborreliosis), which would be an indication for treatment with penicillin G.

E) INCORRECT:

Macrolides (e.g., azithromycin) are not recommended as a first-line antibiotic in patients with Lyme disease. Because bacterial resistance to macrolides is increasing and they are generally not as effective as other antibiotics, macrolides are only given to patients with contraindications to first-line antibiotics.
questions.hint: This patient's circular red rash with central clearing (erythema migrans) and flu-like symptoms (headaches, myalgias) following a recent camping trip to an endemic area (Northeast and Upper Midwest of the US) should raise concern for early localized Lyme disease, which typically occurs 7–14 days after a tick bite. The papular skin findings on her lower legs and forearms are likely due to mosquito bites.

questions.text: A 29-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 3-day history of a swollen right knee. Over the past 6 weeks, he has had painful episodes affecting the right knee and the left elbow. He previously had a rash, which subsided 2 months ago. He lives in Connecticut and works as a landscaper. He is sexually active with one female partner and uses condoms consistently. His temperature is 37.8°C (100.0°F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 12/min, and blood pressure is 110/75 mm Hg. Physical examination shows a tender and warm right knee; range of motion is limited by pain. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. His hematocrit is 44%, leukocyte count is 10,300/mm3, and platelet count is 145,000/mm3. Serum electrolyte concentrations are within normal limits. Arthrocentesis of the right knee is performed and the synovial fluid appears cloudy. Gram stain is negative. Analysis of the synovial fluid shows a leukocyte count of 27,000/mm3 and 80% neutrophils. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Lyme disease often manifests with a localized rash (i.e., erythema chronicum migrans) and can ultimately lead to systemic infection involving the joints, skin, and central nervous system. The incidence of Lyme disease is highest in the Northeast and upper Midwest of the US and outdoor workers (e.g., rangers, landscapers, farmers) are at an increased risk of infection. Patients may initially have arthralgia or myalgia as a part of the flu-like symptoms of stage I disease. Stage II disease can manifest with migratory arthralgia, which can progress to Lyme arthritis (i.e., stage III; late Lyme disease) if left untreated. Arthrocentesis findings in patients with Lyme arthritis typically include yellow cloudy fluid, leukocytosis with neutrophilic predominance, the absence of crystals, and a negative Gram stain and culture; however, these findings are nonspecific. This patient's presentation of arthritis of the knee, preceded by several weeks of migratory arthralgia, in combination with the arthrocentesis findings is consistent with Lyme arthritis.

Two-step serological testing is indicated to confirm the exposure: An ELISA test should be used as a screening test followed by a Western blot to detect IgG and IgM antibodies against Borrelia burgdorferi. PCR testing of the synovial fluid can be used to confirm the diagnosis in patients with suspected Lyme arthritis who are IgG immunoblot-positive.

B) INCORRECT:

Osteoarthritis commonly affects the knees. However, pain associated with osteoarthritis is isolated to the affected joints and typically worsens toward the end of the day and/or following physical activity, as opposed to the episodic, migratory course seen in this patient. Osteoarthritis also most commonly affects individuals > 65 years of age. Furthermore, this patient's arthrocentesis findings indicate a different process.

C) INCORRECT:

Rheumatoid arthritis is characterized by symmetrical joint involvement (especially of the MCP and PIP joints) rather than migratory arthralgia, as seen in this patient. Other characteristic findings in rheumatoid arthritis include morning stiffness (> 30 minutes), joint deformities (e.g., swan neck deformities, boutonniere deformities, ulnar deviation), and extraarticular manifestations (e.g., constitutional symptoms), none of which are seen here.

D) INCORRECT:

Gonococcal arthritis is caused by Neisseria gonorrhea, the most common cause of septic arthritis in sexually active young adults. Common manifestations of gonococcal arthritis include fever, chills, progressive rash, migratory polyarthralgia, and/or tenosynovitis. In addition, isolated purulent gonococcal arthritis typically manifests as monoarthritis (e.g., of the knee), as seen here, or asymmetric oligoarthritis. Gram staining is often negative and more than half of cases have a negative synovial fluid culture. However, leukocyte count is typically > 50,000/mm3 in gonococcal arthritis. In addition, this patient's geographical location and outdoor occupation make another etiology more likely.

E) INCORRECT:

Reactive arthritis is an immune-mediated condition most commonly caused by bacterial infection of the gastrointestinal or urinary tract. Clinical features include arthritis, which is often asymmetrical and migratory, as seen here. In addition, arthrocentesis findings typically include neutrophilic leukocytosis with a negative Gram stain. However, other characteristic features of reactive arthritis, such as conjunctivitis and urethritis, are not present in this patient. In addition, there is no history of recent gastrointestinal or urinary tract infection.
questions.hint: This patient has progressed to stage III of the illness.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man comes to the emergency department for evaluation of right-sided facial weakness that he noticed after waking up. One month ago, he also experienced right-sided neck pain and headache that began after returning from a hunting trip to New Hampshire the week before. He took ibuprofen to relieve symptoms, which subsided a week later. He has a 5-year history of hypertension controlled with drug therapy. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 35 years and he drinks two beers daily. His vital signs are within the normal limits. Physical examination shows right-sided drooping of the upper and lower half of the face. The patient has difficulties smiling and he is unable to close his right eye. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in diagnosis?

choices.text: Polymerase chain reaction of the facial skin
Noncontrast CT scan of the head

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Western blot confirms Lyme disease through the detection of IgG and IgM antibodies against Borrelia, but it is not appropriate for screening.

B) INCORRECT:

PCR of the facial skin can be used to detect various pathogens, including varicella zoster virus and herpes simplex virus (HSV). Herpes zoster oticus is one of the most common infectious causes of facial nerve paralysis, however, the pain and herpetic skin vesicles characteristic of herpes zoster are not present in this patient. Reactivation of HSV is thought to be a trigger of the majority of cases of Bell palsy, but the patient's history of a hunting trip in association with his symptoms is highly suspicious for Lyme disease.

C) INCORRECT:

CSF analysis via lumbar puncture is not used as an initial test for diagnosing Lyme disease. Although CSF findings would include signs of lymphocytic meningitis (elevated protein and pleocytosis) and intrathecal Borrelia-specific IgG and IgM antibodies can be detected via immunoblot, an LP is an invasive test and serological testing would be more appropriate. CSF analysis is, however, used to rule out other specific causes of facial nerve palsy, including Guillain-Barré syndrome (GBS), multiple sclerosis (MS), and meningitis. Facial nerve palsy is a rare finding in these conditions though, and other simultaneous typical clinical features of these conditions would be expected.

D) CORRECT:

Enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA) is the screening test of choice for Lyme disease. Peripheral facial nerve paralysis is the most common cranial neuropathy in Lyme disease. If ELISA is positive, Western blot should be performed to confirm the diagnosis.

E) INCORRECT:

Noncontrast CT scan of the head is warranted for facial nerve palsy if trauma or tumor are suspected, or if the clinical features are atypical, progress > 3 weeks, or persist > 4 months. It is also the initial test of choice for suspected stroke, an important differential diagnosis of facial nerve palsy in this patient given his history of smoking and hypertension. However, stroke is typically associated with central facial nerve paralysis that spares the forehead, which is not the case here. Other symptoms of stroke, including contralateral hemiparesis and homonymous hemianopia, are also absent. Rarely, a stroke in the brainstem involving the LMN of the facial nerve can cause ipsilateral peripheral nerve palsy, but other symptoms (e.g., vertebrobasilar insufficiency) would also be expected.
questions.hint: This patient has peripheral facial nerve palsy, which can be caused by Lyme disease. The presence of unilateral neck pain and headache following a hunting trip to an area where Lyme disease is endemic (the Northeast and upper Midwest of the US) is consistent with this diagnosis.

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because she has had dyspnea and palpitations with mild exertion for the past 8 days. Initially, the symptoms subsided immediately after cessation of activity, but they have worsened and now last up to 45 minutes. The patient returned from a summer camping trip in Vermont 6 weeks ago. She says she had “an episode of flu” with fever and chills 1 month ago. She has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. Her father had a myocardial infarction at the age of 56 years. She drinks two to four beers on social occasions and occasionally smokes marijuana. Her temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 47/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 150/70 mm Hg. A resting ECG is shown. Two-step serological testing confirms the diagnosis. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

In a young patient with cardiac symptoms (e.g., palpitations, dyspnea), AV block, or other cardiac arrhythmias a few weeks to months after a possible infection with Borrelia burgdorferi, there should be a high level of suspicion for Lyme carditis. Cardiac manifestations are a feature of early disseminated Lyme disease, which typically occurs 3–10 weeks after a tick bite. Intravenous ceftriaxone is the first-line treatment for adults and children with severe Lyme carditis (i.e., symptomatic patients, first-degree AV block with PR interval ≥ 300 ms, second- or third-degree AV block). Other severe manifestations of Lyme disease that warrant hospitalization and intravenous antibiotic therapy include encephalopathy, polyneuropathy, and persistent arthritis.

Less severe manifestations of Lyme disease (e.g., mild carditis, isolated cranial nerve palsy, migratory arthralgias) should be treated with oral doxycycline or amoxicillin (in patients who are pregnant or lactating).

B) INCORRECT:

Oral amoxicillin is the first-line treatment for pregnant or lactating patients with Lyme disease who do not require hospitalization, such as those with mild carditis (i.e., first-degree AV block with PR interval < 300 ms). In patients with more severe manifestations of Lyme disease, another form of therapy is indicated.

C) INCORRECT:

As beta blockers have negative inotropic, dromotropic, and chronotropic effects, which typically lead to decreased blood pressure and decreased oxygen consumption by the heart, they can be used to treat hypertension and heart failure. Beta-blocker therapy would likely worsen this patient's bradycardia and is contraindicated in patients with AV block.

D) INCORRECT:

Oral doxycycline is the first-line treatment for most patients with Lyme disease who do not require hospitalization, such as those with mild carditis (i.e., first-degree AV block with PR interval < 300 ms). In patients with more severe manifestations of Lyme disease, another form of therapy is indicated.

E) INCORRECT:

Atropine, a muscarinic antagonist, may be indicated in cases of bradycardia. However, the patient is young, hemodynamically stable, and her symptoms are not severe. Furthermore, she has an AV block associated with early disseminated Lyme disease, so it is important to first treat the underlying cause. Additionally, atropine affects the sinus node as opposed to the AV node.

F) INCORRECT:

Permanent pacemaker implantation is not usually necessary to treat an AV block caused by Lyme carditis. Temporary pacemaker implantation may be required, however, in severe cases (e.g., second-degree AV block, Mobitz II or third-degree AV block) or in patients who are hemodynamically unstable.
questions.hint: Although no tick bite or rash (erythema migrans) have been reported, an episode of flu-like symptoms shortly after a camping trip to an endemic area (Northeast and Upper Midwest of the US) should raise concern for Lyme disease, which is diagnosed with two-step serological testing (ELISA followed by Western blot). The ECG strip shows progressively longer PR intervals before a QRS is dropped and resets the cycle, indicating second-degree AV block, Mobitz I.

questions.text: A 24-year-old female comes to the physician because of flu-like symptoms and a new rash for 2 days. She denies contacts with sick individuals or recent travel abroad, but recently went camping in Vermont. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination of the lateral right thigh shows a circular red ring with central clearing. Which of the following is the natural reservoir of the pathogen responsible for this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Rats are reservoir hosts of Leptospira spp., which causes leptospirosis, and Yersinia pestis, which causes plague. Both conditions present with flu-like symptoms, as in this patient. However, the absence of classic findings of leptospirosis (macular rash, conjunctivitis) and plague (painful swollen lymph nodes), make these diagnoses unlikely. Rats are not a natural reservoir for the pathogen responsible for this patient's symptoms.

B) CORRECT:

In the US, the primary reservoir host for Borrelia burgdorferi, the pathogen responsible for Lyme disease, is the white-footed mouse (Peromyscus leucopus). Another host is the white-tailed deer. The Ixodes tick is the main vector responsible for transmission to humans.
Image Description:

A large, primary lesion with circular erythema and central clearing on the posterior side of the right upper arm is visible.

This clinical picture is typical of erythema migrans (stage-I Lyme disease).

Illustration: Bull's eye sign

C) INCORRECT:

Cattle are reservoir hosts of several pathogens, including Coxiella burnetii, which causes Q fever, as well as Brucella spp., which causes brucellosis. They are not, however, a reservoir for Borrelia burgdorferi, the underlying pathogen in Lyme disease.

D) INCORRECT:

Rabbits are reservoir hosts of Francisella tularensis, which causes tularemia. Flu-like symptoms occur in both Lyme disease and tularemia; however, the skin finding associated with tularemia is an ulcer at the site of pathogen entry, not erythema migrans. Rabbits are not reservoirs for Borrelia burgdorferi, the pathogen responsible for Lyme disease.

E) INCORRECT:

The Ixodes tick is the main vector responsible for transmission of Borrelia burgdorferi, the underlying pathogen in Lyme disease, to humans. Ticks are not, however, considered a natural reservoir for this bacterium, which requires the ability to live, grow, and multiply within its host.

F) INCORRECT:

Fleas act as a vector for Yersinia pestis, which causes plague, as well as Rickettsia typhi, which causes typhus. Both conditions present with flu-like symptoms, as in this patient; however, the absence of classic findings of plague (painful swollen lymph nodes) and typhus (maculopapular truncal rash), make these diagnoses unlikely. Fleas are not a natural reservoir for the pathogen responsible for this patient's symptoms.
questions.hint: The circular bullseye rash (erythema migrans) and flu-like symptoms seen in this patient after a recent camping trip raise concern for Lyme disease.

questions.text: A 21-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 3-week history of a rash. Five days ago, he also developed joint pain in his right knee that has now moved to his right ankle. The patient reports going camping in Vermont 2 months ago. Upon questioning about potential tick bites, he says “I don't remember seeing any ticks on my skin, but it's certainly possible.” He has no history of recent illness. His medical history is significant for asthma treated with an albuterol inhaler. His pulse is 54/min, and blood pressure is 110/72 mm Hg. Physical examination shows several red rings with central clearing on the right arm and chest. Range of motion is normal in all joints. Muscle strength is 5/5 in all extremities. Without adequate treatment, this patient is at highest risk for which of the following complications?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Cranial nerve palsy (most commonly peripheral facial nerve palsy) is a common complication of stage II Lyme disease that is caused by early neuroborreliosis. Further manifestations of early neuroborreliosis include meningitis and asymmetrical polyneuropathy. Stage II Lyme disease can also manifest with Lyme carditis (e.g., cardiac arrhythmias such as AV block), borrelial lymphocytoma, and ocular manifestations (e.g., retinal vasculitis, keratitis). Diagnosis is mainly clinical but can be supported by two-step serologic testing (enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay followed by Western blot). Because this patient has bradycardia, an urgent electrocardiogram should also be performed to evaluate for AV block. Doxycycline is the drug of choice for mild early disseminated Lyme disease, while ceftriaxone is indicated for severe illness.

Early localized (stage I) Lyme disease commonly manifests with a singular erythema migrans (EM) lesion and flulike symptoms (e.g., myalgias, arthralgias). Late (stage III) Lyme disease is characterized by Lyme arthritis, late neuroborreliosis, and, rarely, acrodermatitis chronica atrophicans.

B) INCORRECT:

Glomerular damage can be indicative of IgA vasculitis, which can manifest with both arthritis and a rash. The rash of IgA vasculitis, however, is typically described as raised, erythematous, symmetrically distributed macules or urticarial lesions which coalesce into palpable purpura (nonblanching skin lesions). This patient's rash does not fit this description. In addition, IgA vasculitis typically manifests after an upper respiratory infection; this patient has no history of a recent illness.

C) INCORRECT:

Heart valve stenosis can be a complication of rheumatic fever, which may manifest with migratory arthritis of large joints, heart involvement, and an expanding ring-like rash with central clearing (erythema marginatum). This patient has neither a history of Streptococcus pyogenes infection (e.g., strep throat) nor further expected symptoms of rheumatic fever such as constitutional symptoms, Sydenham chorea, or subcutaneous nodules. Additionally, rheumatic fever is increasingly uncommon in high-income countries because of improved hygiene standards, a decline in infections with rheumatogenic strains of streptococci, and the routine use of antibiotics for streptococcal pharyngitis. This patient's history of camping in a region endemic for Lyme disease makes a different complication more likely.

D) INCORRECT:

Bone marrow failure can be indicative of an aplastic crisis, which is a complication of a parvovirus B19 infection. Parvovirus B19 can manifest with both arthritis and dermatitis; however, children are more likely to develop the “slapped-cheek rash” without joint involvement, while adults often develop symmetrical polyarthritis (fingers, hands, knees, and ankles) without dermatologic manifestations. This patient's migratory, asymmetric arthritis of the large joints is more likely to have a different cause.

E) INCORRECT:

Liver capsule inflammation can be a finding of Fitz-Hugh-Curtis syndrome, a rare complication of pelvic inflammatory disease secondary to gonorrhea. While disseminated gonococcal infection can also manifest with migratory arthritis and dermatitis, the rash is expected to be pustular or vesicular and accompanied by tenosynovitis. Furthermore, Fitz-Hugh-Curtis syndrome occurs almost exclusively in women.
questions.hint: A history of camping in an endemic region (regardless of whether patients can recall tick bites) in conjunction with multiple erythema migrans (EM) lesions and migratory arthralgia suggests early disseminated (stage II) Lyme disease.

questions.text: A 31-year-old woman, gravida 1, para 0, at 10 weeks' gestation comes to the physician because of a rash on her upper arm that appeared 3 days ago. She has also had headaches and muscle aches for 1 day. She went on a camping trip in Maine 10 days ago. Her temperature is 39°C (102.2°F). A photograph of her rash is shown. The most appropriate initial pharmacotherapy in this patient has which of the following mechanisms of action?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Inhibition of DNA gyrase is the mechanism of action of fluoroquinolones, which are absolutely contraindicated in pregnant women because of the risk of fetal cartilage damage. Moreover, most fluoroquinolones are typically ineffective against spirochetes.

B) INCORRECT:

Inhibition of ergosterol synthesis is the mechanism of action of azoles (e.g., clotrimazole), which are used to treat fungal infections such as tinea corporis. Tinea corporis can manifest as an annular erythematous rash with a central clearing but the rash would have a scaly border and is not associated with systemic symptoms (e.g., headache, myalgias). This patient most likely has a bacterial infection and ergosterol is not a bacterial component.
Image Description:

An erythematous patch with mild scaling and central clearing is seen on the left wrist.

These features are characteristic of dermatophyte fungal infection.

C) INCORRECT:

Inhibition of mycolic acid synthesis is the mechanism of action of isoniazid, an antituberculous drug. Mycolic acid is present in Mycobacteria spp. but absent in spirochetes.

D) INCORRECT:

Inhibition of dihydropteroate synthase is the mechanism of action of sulfonamides and dapsone, both of which are typically ineffective against spirochetes. Moreover, sulfonamide antibiotics are absolutely contraindicated in pregnant women because of the risk of kernicterus in the newborn and dapsone is relatively contraindicated because the safety of dapsone in this population has not been well established.

E) CORRECT:

Doxycycline, which works by binding to the 30S ribosomal subunit and inhibiting protein synthesis, is the first-line treatment for Lyme disease but is relatively contraindicated in pregnant and nursing women because of its adverse effects on the growing bones and teeth of the fetus or newborn (doxycycline is safer than older tetracyclines, which are absolutely contraindicated in pregnant and nursing women). Certain penicillin antibiotics (e.g., amoxicillin, penicillin G) and certain cephalosporins of the second generation (e.g., cefuroxime axetil) or third generation (e.g., ceftriaxone) are used to treat Lyme disease in pregnant or nursing women. Inhibition of peptidoglycan cross-linking in the bacterial cell wall is the mechanism of action of penicillin, cephalosporin, carbapenem, and monobactam antibiotics.
Image Description:

A. Bacterial cell envelope
- Polymyxins disrupt the outer membrane that is present in gram-negative bacteria.
- Beta-lactams, glycopeptides, and epoxides inhibit cell wall synthesis.
- Daptomycin forms ion channels on the cell membrane that lead to membrane depolarization and disruption.

B. Nucleic acids and related enzymes
- Nitroimidazoles disrupt DNA strands by creating free radicals.
- Fluoroquinolones interrupt DNA replication by inhibiting prokaryotic DNA gyrase.
- Rifamycin prevents transcription by inhibiting RNA polymerase.

C. Bacterial ribosomes
- Macrolides, amphenicols, lincosamides, and oxazolidinones inhibit protein synthesis by binding to the 50s subunit of the bacterial ribosome.
- Aminoglycosides, tetracyclines, and glycylcyclines inhibit protein synthesis by binding to the 30s subunit of the bacterial ribosome.

D. Folic acid metabolism (required for DNA synthesis)
- Sulfamethoxazole inhibits bacterial purine synthesis by inhibiting dihydropteroate synthetase, which converts para-aminobenzoate (PABA) into dihydrofolate (DHF).
- Trimethoprim, a diaminopyrimidine, inhibits bacterial purine synthesis by inhibiting dihydrofolate reductase, which converts DHF into tetrahydrofolate (THF).
questions.hint: This patient's rash is consistent with erythema migrans, which is pathognomonic for early localized Lyme disease. The pathogen responsible for Lyme disease is the spirochete Borrelia burgdorferi.

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 4-day history of swelling and pain in her left knee. She has had similar episodes of swollen joints over the past 3 weeks. Two months ago, she had a rash on her upper back that subsided after a few days. She lives in Pennsylvania and works as a forest ranger. Her temperature is 37.8°C (100°F). Physical examination shows a tender and warm left knee. Arthrocentesis of the knee joint yields cloudy fluid with a leukocyte count of 30,000/mm3 and 80% neutrophils. A Gram stain of synovial fluid does not show any organisms. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's condition?

choices.text: Production of autoantibodies against Fc portion of IgG
Infection with round bacteria in clusters
Postinfectious activation of innate lymphoid cells of the gut
Infection with round bacteria in pairs of two

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Production of autoantibodies against the Fc portion of IgG would be consistent with rheumatoid arthritis (RA), which is characterized by the inflammation of several joints, elevated body temperature, and cloudy synovial fluid with a negative culture. However, RA would involve symmetrical inflammation of the metacarpophalangeal and proximal interphalangeal joints, not the knee. It would manifest with morning stiffness, moreover, rather than a rash. Additionally, arthrocentesis in RA would show a decreased WBC count, not the elevated count seen in this patient. Finally, the fact that this patient lives in the Northeast and works outdoors makes another type of infection more likely.

B) INCORRECT:

Wearing down either of articular cartilage would be consistent with osteoarthritis, which would manifest with pain, swelling, and tenderness of the knee joint. However, symptoms of osteoarthritis are due to degeneration, not inflammation, making an elevated body temperature and joint swelling and warmth unlikely. Osteoarthritis also typically occurs in individuals > 65 years of age and would not manifest with a rash or cloudy synovial fluid. Furthermore, the fact that this patient lives in the Northeast and works outdoors makes another type of infection more likely.

C) INCORRECT:

Infection with round bacteria in clusters indicates Staphylococcus aureus, the most common cause of septic arthritis, which would manifest with inflammation of the knee joint and elevated body temperature. However, septic arthritis typically involves infection of a single joint (monoarthritis) and is characterized by an acute onset and course. A rash would also not be expected before the onset of arthritis. Moreover, arthrocentesis would show a yellowish-green, turbid fluid with an elevated WBC count (neutrophil predominant), and Gram staining would show gram-positive cocci. Finally, the fact that this patient lives in the Northeast and works outdoors makes another type of infection more likely.

D) INCORRECT:

Postinfectious activation of innate lymphoid cells of the gut is consistent with reactive arthritis due to Campylobacter jejuni infection, which can manifest with inflammation of several joints (polyarthritis), a skin lesion, elevated body temperature, and synovial fluid that does not show any organism. However, the skin lesion would typically be located on the glans (balanitis circinata) or present as a hyperkeratinization of the palms and soles (keratoderma blenorrhagicum), but a rash would not be expected on the trunk. Arthritis is usually preceded by a gastrointestinal or urogenital infection, and arthrocentesis would only reveal a mildly elevated WBC count (< 40,000/μL). Additionally, the fact that this patient lives in the Northeast and works outdoors makes another type of infection more likely.

E) INCORRECT:

Infection with round bacteria in pairs of two indicates a diplococcus, e.g., Neisseria gonorrhoeae, the causative pathogen of gonococcal arthritis, which is the most common form of arthritis resulting of a disseminated genitourinary tract infection in sexually active young adults. Gonococcal arthritis can manifest with inflammation of several joints (polyarthralgia), an elevated body temperature, a rash on the trunk, and arthrocentesis showing a cloudy fluid with an increased WBC count. However, Gram staining would show gram-negative diplococci, and the fact that this patient lives in the Northeast and works outdoors makes another type of infection more likely.

F) CORRECT:

Borrelia burgdorferi is a tick-borne spiral-shaped bacteria that causes Lyme disease, which typically begins with a localized rash (i.e., erythema chronicum migrans) and ultimately can cause systemic infection involving the joints, skin, and central nervous system. The incidence of lyme disease is highest in the Northeast and upper Midwest of the US, and outdoor workers (e.g., rangers, landscapers, farmers) are at an increased risk of infection. The nonspecific arthrocentesis findings, i.e., negative Gram stain and leukocytosis with increased neutrophils are consistent with Lyme arthritis. Two-step serological testing is indicated to confirm exposure: The screening test ELISA should be followed by a Western blot test to detect IgG and IgM antibodies against Borrelia. However, positive results only demonstrate exposure to Borrelia, not necessarily current infection. PCR (arthrocentesis) is best for confirming suspected Lyme arthritis in patients who are IgG immunoblot-positive. The treatment for Lyme arthritis in adults is oral doxycycline.
questions.hint: This patient has progressed to stage III of the illness.

questions.text: A 29-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department after an episode of syncope. For the past 10 days, she has had dyspnea and palpitations occurring with mild exertion. The patient returned from a hiking trip in Upstate New York 5 weeks ago. Except for an episode of flu with fever and chills a month ago, she has no history of serious illness. Her temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), pulse is 45/min, respirations are 21/min, and blood pressure is 148/72 mm Hg. A resting ECG is shown. Two-step serological testing confirms the diagnosis. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Intravenous therapy is indicated for severe Lyme carditis associated with arrhythmias and most other manifestations of disseminated Lyme disease, which typically occurs 3–10 weeks after a tick bite. The first-line intravenous medication is ceftriaxone, a third-generation cephalosporin. Doxycycline is the preferred oral agent for Lyme disease when oral treatment is indicated. Although the patient did not report a tick bite or specific signs of early, localized Lyme disease (e.g., erythema migrans), she did have nonspecific flu-like symptoms one week after her camping trip, and a clinician should be highly suspicious of Lyme carditis in a young patient presenting with syncope, palpitations, dyspnea, and Mobitz type I 2nd-degree AV block 5 weeks after a camping trip to a Lyme disease-endemic area. Diagnosis should be confirmed via serology before beginning antibiotic therapy.

After outdoor activities in areas endemic for Lyme disease, disseminated Lyme disease should be ruled out as the cause of cardiac, neurological, and joint problems, especially because erythema migrans only occurs in approx. 80% of infected individuals.

B) INCORRECT:

Vitamin B1 (thiamine) supplementation may be indicated in the case of thiamine deficiency, which can cause wet beriberi. Wet beriberi is characterized by high-output cardiac failure (dilated cardiomyopathy), cardiomegaly, and edema. Thiamine deficiency typically occurs in cases of chronic alcohol consumption, malnutrition, and starvation. The vignette does not mention any of these risk factors nor edema.

Similarly, thiamine deficiency can cause dry beriberi, which is characterized mainly by neurological symptoms resulting from damaged peripheral nerves.

C) INCORRECT:

Beta blockers have negative inotropic, dromotropic, and chronotropic effects, which typically lead to decreased blood pressure and decreased oxygen consumption by the heart and can thus be used to treat hypertension and heart failure. Beta blockers would actually worsen the patient's bradycardia (her pulse is 45/min) and are contraindicated if there is an AV block.

D) INCORRECT:

Oral amoxicillin, a beta-lactam antibiotic, is used to treat localized and some manifestations of early disseminated Lyme disease (including mild carditis) in patients < 8 years old and in pregnant and lactating women. However, in the case of Lyme carditis with a 2nd-degree AV block, another form of therapy is indicated.

E) INCORRECT:

Oral doxycycline, a tetracycline, is used to treat patients with localized and some manifestations of early disseminated Lyme disease, including mild carditis. However, in the case of Lyme carditis with a 2nd-degree AV block, intravenous therapy is indicated.

F) INCORRECT:

Atropine, a muscarinic antagonist, may be indicated in cases of bradycardia. However, the patient is young, hemodynamically stable, and her symptoms are not severe. Furthermore, she has an AV block associated with early disseminated Lyme disease, so it is important to first treat the underlying cause. Additionally, atropine affects the sinus node as opposed to the AV node.

G) INCORRECT:

A permanent pacemaker implantation is not usually necessary to treat an AV block caused by Lyme carditis. Severe cases (e.g., Mobitz type II 2nd-degree AV block, 3rd degree AV block) or hemodynamically unstable patients may require temporary pacemaker implantation, however.
questions.hint: The ECG strip shows progressively longer PR intervals before a QRS is dropped and resets the cycle, which indicates a Mobitz type I 2nd-degree AV block (Wenckebach). Based on the history of a hiking trip in the Northeast followed by flu-like symptoms, and the positive serology testing, early disseminated Lyme disease is the most likely cause for this patient's symptoms and the finding of AV block.

questions.text:
A 40-year-old woman is hospitalized for evaluation of 2 days of severe fatigue and an abnormal electrocardiogram that revealed complete heart block and a junctional escape rhythm at 48 beats per minute.
Six weeks earlier, following a camping trip, the patient had a fever, diffuse joint and muscle aches, and a circular rash on her thigh, which have since resolved.
On examination, she is afebrile with a heart rate of 48 beats per minute, a blood pressure of 110/70 mm Hg, and an oxygen saturation of 98% while she is breathing ambient air.
Which one of the following treatments is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Oral doxycycline and oral amoxicillin are used to treat early, nondisseminated Lyme disease (e.g., erythema migrans).

B) INCORRECT:

Glucocorticoids, such as prednisone, are not used to treat Lyme carditis.

C) INCORRECT:

Most patients with Lyme-related conduction defects do not require a permanent pacemaker if appropriately treated. A temporary pacemaker is appropriate only in cases of hemodynamic instability or unstable escape rhythms.

D) CORRECT:

Lyme disease is a tick-borne spirochetal disease caused by Borrelia burgdorferi. Initial symptoms include fever, myalgias, arthralgias, and a characteristic circular rash (erythema migrans). Cardiac involvement typically manifests as conduction disease but may include other arrhythmias, myocarditis, pericarditis, or pericardial effusion. Affected patients can have first-, second-, or third-degree atrioventricular block. Generally, the conduction disturbance is located at or above the atrioventricular node and is reversible with antibiotic treatment.

Lyme disease-related heart block with junctional escape merits antibiotic therapy with intravenous ceftriaxone. Once improvement is seen, the patient may be switched to oral antibiotics to complete a total of 14 to 21 days of antibiotics.

Key learning point: The typical cardiac manifestation of Lyme disease is high-degree atrioventricular block, generally reversible with appropriate antibiotic therapy.

E) INCORRECT:

Oral doxycycline and oral amoxicillin are used to treat early, nondisseminated Lyme disease (e.g., erythema migrans).

questions.text:
A 48-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with fatigue and lethargy. One month ago, she experienced fever, rash, and arthralgias that appeared the week after a backpacking excursion.
She has a heart rate of 39 beats per minute and a blood pressure of 80/42 mm Hg. She is not in respiratory distress. Her jugular venous pulse reveals intermittent large “a” waves. Her cardiac examination is notable only for bradycardia. She has no peripheral edema or rash.
An electrocardiogram is obtained (figure).
In addition to placing pads on the patient’s chest for transcutaneous pacing, which one of the following next steps is most appropriate?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Ibutilide is used to establish normal sinus rhythm in a patient with atrial flutter or fibrillation; it is not indicated for complete heart block.

B) INCORRECT:

Adenosine, which slows conduction time through the atrioventricular node, is contraindicated in a patient with complete heart block.

C) INCORRECT:

Atropine often transiently improves the ventricular rate if the site of block is in the atrioventricular node. Atropine is unlikely to be successful in wide-complex bradyarrhythmias, where the level of the block is below the level of the atrioventricular node.

D) INCORRECT:

Electrical cardioversion is appropriate for managing unstable tachyarrhythmias but not for complete heart block.

E) CORRECT:

This patient’s electrocardiogram reveals complete heart block, which is likely to be caused by Lyme disease. Lyme-related carditis usually occurs within weeks to months of onset of infection and most often manifests as atrioventricular conduction block, with up to half of affected patients developing complete heart block.

In complete heart block, an obvious relationship between the P waves and the QRS complexes is not present, and a ventricular escape rhythm is evident. Large jugular venous “a” waves or “cannon a” waves are large venous pulse waves produced when the atrium contracts against a closed tricuspid valve; such dyssynchronous contractions of the atrium during ventricular systole can occur with complete heart block.

Management of symptomatic complete heart block depends on the acuity of the patient’s presentation:

• If the patient is in shock due to low cardiac output, transcutaneous pacing should be initiated immediately. Administration of dopamine or epinephrine may be reasonable as a temporizing measure while the clinician awaits the availability of a pacemaker.
• If the patient is somewhat more stable (as in this case), the clinician may prefer to hold off on transcutaneous pacing, given the discomfort associated with this intervention. Instead, the pacing pads can be placed on the patient’s chest so that if the patient’s clinical status deteriorates while arrangements for the transvenous pacemaker are being made, transcutaneous pacing can be initiated rapidly.

Key learning point: The most appropriate treatment for a patient with complete heart block is transcutaneous or transvenous pacing.

questions.text:
A 38-year-old woman reports a one-week history of worsening swelling, stiffness, and pain in her right knee. She denies fevers, chills, and neurologic symptoms. She is afebrile and has normal vital signs. Her right knee has a moderate effusion without significant erythema. Flexing the knee causes her some pain. Her neurologic examination is normal. The patient recalls developing an erythematous circular rash after a tick bite several months ago.
Fluid from an arthrocentesis reveals a leukocyte count of 25,000 per mm3 and a negative Gram stain. A culture is negative at 72 hours.
Which one of the following antibiotic regimens is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Patients with Lyme-associated arthritis typically present with a culture-negative inflammatory arthritis. There may also be a history of a known tick bite, a recent circular rash (erythema migrans), or both. Lyme-associated arthritis can be a manifestation of early disseminated disease but is often associated with late disseminated disease months to years after initial infection. It may be monoarticular or oligoarticular, intermittent or chronic, and most commonly affects the knees. The diagnosis of Lyme arthritis is supported by the presence of positive Lyme-disease serology testing, supporting history and symptoms, and the absence of a positive culture from synovial fluid.

The first-line treatment for Lyme arthritis is oral doxycycline, amoxicillin, or cefuroxime axetil for 28 days. A second round of antibiotics is appropriate for patients with symptoms that persist despite treatment. In some cases, arthritis remains as a permanent sequela and is managed supportively.

Key learning point: The most appropriate first-line antibiotic therapy for Lyme-associated arthritis is doxycycline, amoxicillin, or cefuroxime axetil for 28 days.

B) INCORRECT:

Fluoroquinolones, such as moxifloxacin, are not recommended for treating Lyme disease.

C) INCORRECT:

Cephalexin is not active against Lyme disease.

D) INCORRECT:

Parenteral therapy with ceftriaxone is reserved for Lyme-associated arthritis that does not respond to oral therapy. Prolonged therapy with intravenous ceftriaxone is not indicated.

E) INCORRECT:

In early Lyme disease, azithromycin is inferior to amoxicillin and is not routinely recommended for Lyme arthritis.

questions.text:
A 48-year-old Massachusetts resident presents with a one-month history of left-knee pain without antecedent trauma. During the past month, the left knee has become progressively more swollen. She is sexually active with her husband, and they are in a monogamous relationship.
Physical examination reveals a warm left knee with a large effusion. There are no skin lesions. Arthrocentesis of the left knee reveals a leukocyte count of 24,000/mm3 with 75% neutrophils and no crystals. Gram’s stain and cultures are negative. Radiographs of the knee are normal. Testing of urine, pharyngeal, and rectal samples is negative for gonorrhea and chlamydia infection.
Which one of the following conditions is most important to rule out next in this case?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Rheumatoid arthritis (RA) typically causes symmetric polyarthritis in both small and large joints. Although RA can sometimes present as an inflammatory monoarthritis, it is most important to first rule out Lyme arthritis as a disease entity in endemic parts of the country.

B) INCORRECT:

Granulomatosis with polyangiitis (formerly referred to as Wegener’s) typically causes arthralgias (often migratory) or polyarthritis without large effusions. In addition, this patient lacks other features of this condition, such as sinusitis, cutaneous vasculitis, and pulmonary or kidney disease.

C) INCORRECT:

Gonococcal arthritis should be suspected as the cause of monoarthritis in sexually active patients. The Gram’s stain of the synovial fluid is negative in 75% of cases; synovial fluid cultures are negative in >50%. However, this patient has no new sexual partners and multiple study results showing no evidence of gonococcus.

D) CORRECT:

Lyme disease, endemic in the northeastern United States, has three disease stages: early localized, early disseminated, and late disseminated. Lyme arthritis occurs in approximately 60% of untreated patients during the late-disseminated phase, months after initial infection. The joint most often affected is the knee, and large joint effusions are common.

Key learning point: Patients with late disseminated Lyme disease may present with inflammatory monoarthritis.

E) INCORRECT:

Systemic lupus erythematosus also typically causes a symmetric, nondeforming polyarthritis.

questions.text:
A 45-year-old man presents for follow-up after he was diagnosed with Lyme disease 8 months ago during evaluation of left-knee pain and swelling. The symptoms have persisted since diagnosis despite completion of a 28-day course of doxycycline followed by a 28-day course of intravenous ceftriaxone. The patient is taking nonsteroidal antiinflammatory agents, but these have been largely ineffective. His history is otherwise notable only for hypertension treated with hydrochlorothiazide. He has no known drug allergies.
His vital signs are within normal limits. On physical examination, he has boggy swelling of the left knee, with a moderate-size effusion, and the knee is warm to the touch.
Enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA) testing for antibodies to Borrelia burgdorferi is positive. Western blot testing is negative for immunoglobulin M and positive for immunoglobulin G bands at 18, 23, 39, 41, 45, and 66 kD.
A knee arthrocentesis reveals 4500 nucleated cells with 75% neutrophils. No crystals are identified. Gram stain, culture, and Lyme polymerase chain-reaction testing of the synovial fluid are negative.
Which one of the following treatments is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Ceftriaxone 2 g daily for an additional 4 weeks
Doxycycline 100 mg twice daily for an additional 4 weeks
Ceftriaxone 2 g daily for an additional 6 months

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Allopurinol is a urate-lowering drug used to treat gout. This patient’s history is not consistent with acute gout, and his synovial fluid does not reveal evidence of urate crystals, as would be typically seen in gout.

B) INCORRECT:

Although this patient’s synovial fluid showed leukocytes, polymerase chain-reaction testing of the fluid was negative, demonstrating inflammation but not active infection. Although this patient’s immunoglobulin G (IgG) result for Lyme disease was positive (≥5 bands), this finding is not indicative of active infection; IgG results can remain positive for 10 to 20 years after onset of Lyme disease. Given the absence of active Lyme infection in this case, further antibiotic therapy (e.g., with doxycycline or ceftriaxone) is not warranted.

According to current guidelines, adults with Lyme arthritis and no clinical evidence of neurologic disease should initially be treated with a 4-week course of oral doxycycline, amoxicillin, or cefuroxime axetil. If the joint swelling persists or recurs, a 2- to 4-week course of intravenous ceftriaxone is recommended. If the joint symptoms continue despite 8 weeks of antibiotic therapy, including 4 weeks of intravenous treatment, the condition is described as postantibiotic Lyme arthritis.

C) INCORRECT:

Although this patient’s synovial fluid showed leukocytes, polymerase chain-reaction testing of the fluid was negative, demonstrating inflammation but not active infection. Although this patient’s immunoglobulin G (IgG) result for Lyme disease was positive (≥5 bands), this finding is not indicative of active infection; IgG results can remain positive for 10 to 20 years after onset of Lyme disease. Given the absence of active Lyme infection in this case, further antibiotic therapy (e.g., with doxycycline or ceftriaxone) is not warranted.

According to current guidelines, adults with Lyme arthritis and no clinical evidence of neurologic disease should initially be treated with a 4-week course of oral doxycycline, amoxicillin, or cefuroxime axetil. If the joint swelling persists or recurs, a 2- to 4-week course of intravenous ceftriaxone is recommended. If the joint symptoms continue despite 8 weeks of antibiotic therapy, including 4 weeks of intravenous treatment, the condition is described as postantibiotic Lyme arthritis.

D) CORRECT:

This patient received appropriate antibiotic therapy for his Lyme arthritis, but he has developed a chronic postantibiotic Lyme arthritis that would likely benefit from treatment with a disease-modifying antirheumatic drug (DMARD), such as methotrexate. Postantibiotic Lyme arthritis is thought to represent a reactive arthritis rather than a persistent infection.

If the joint swelling persists or recurs, a 2- to 4-week course of intravenous ceftriaxone is recommended. If the joint symptoms continue despite 8 weeks of antibiotic therapy, including 4 weeks of intravenous treatment, the condition is described as postantibiotic Lyme arthritis. In such cases, effective treatment can be provided with nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drugs (NSAIDS), intra-articular glucocorticoid injections, conventional synthetic DMARDs (methotrexate, hydroxychloroquine), biologic DMARDs (tumor necrosis factor inhibitors), or arthroscopic synovectomy.

Key learning point: The appropriate treatment for postantibiotic Lyme arthritis in a patient whose synovial fluid is negative for Lyme disease on polymerase chain-reaction testing is a disease-modifying antirheumatic drug, such as methotrexate.

E) INCORRECT:

Although this patient’s synovial fluid showed leukocytes, polymerase chain-reaction testing of the fluid was negative, demonstrating inflammation but not active infection. Although this patient’s immunoglobulin G (IgG) result for Lyme disease was positive (≥5 bands), this finding is not indicative of active infection; IgG results can remain positive for 10 to 20 years after onset of Lyme disease. Given the absence of active Lyme infection in this case, further antibiotic therapy (e.g., with doxycycline or ceftriaxone) is not warranted.

According to current guidelines, adults with Lyme arthritis and no clinical evidence of neurologic disease should initially be treated with a 4-week course of oral doxycycline, amoxicillin, or cefuroxime axetil. If the joint swelling persists or recurs, a 2- to 4-week course of intravenous ceftriaxone is recommended. If the joint symptoms continue despite 8 weeks of antibiotic therapy, including 4 weeks of intravenous treatment, the condition is described as postantibiotic Lyme arthritis.

questions.text:
A previously healthy 6-year-old girl presents for her annual well-child visit with her parents. During the visit, the parents inform you that their family will be going on a camping trip next week. They plan to hike trails that are densely wooded and known to be tick infested. They would like to know how to safely remove an attached tick from their daughter if the need arises.
What is the most appropriate method to remove an attached tick from the child’s skin?

choices.text: Spray the bite site with insect repellant and then use tweezers to rotate the tick gently until it detaches, removing any residual parts with a fingernail
Grasp the tick with tweezers close to the skin and gently twist the tick clockwise and counterclockwise until the tick detaches
Apply a thick coating of petroleum jelly and wait for the tick to detach
Grasp the tick with tweezers close and perpendicular to the skin and gently pull the tick straight out without twisting motions
Light a match and place the flame close to the skin near the tick until the tick detaches

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Ticks should be removed promptly by grasping the tick with fine tweezers and gently pulling it out without twisting motions. Twisting may leave the head of the tick in the skin.Insect repellants are an important preventive measure. However, they do not aid in the removal of ticks that have already attached. Removing a tick with the fingers is not recommended. If fingers must be used to remove a tick, protective barriers for the hands are needed, and the hands should be washed after tick removal.

B) INCORRECT:

Ticks should be removed promptly by grasping the tick with fine tweezers and gently pulling it out without twisting motions. Twisting may leave the head of the tick in the skin.

C) INCORRECT:

Application of petroleum jelly will not suffocate or kill the tick and is an ineffective method of tick removal.

D) CORRECT:

Parents and children should be educated that ticks can transmit diseases, including Lyme disease, babesiosis, ehrlichiosis, anaplasmosis, and Rocky Mountain spotted fever. When children and adults spend time in tick-infested areas, they should wear light-colored clothing that covers the extremities, use insect repellants containing DEET, and check their clothes and skin every 2 to 3 hours. For up to one week after a possible exposure, parents should inspect themselves, their children, and all clothing for ticks.

Ticks should be removed promptly by grasping the tick with fine tweezers and gently pulling it out without twisting motions. Twisting may leave the head of the tick in the skin. The bite site should then be washed with soap and water.

After tick removal, individuals should be monitored closely for signs and symptoms of tickborne diseases for up to 30 days, particularly the development of an expanding erythematous skin lesion at the site of the tick bite (erythema migrans) that may suggest Lyme disease or the development of a febrile illness with or without rash.

Key learning point: The appropriate method to remove an attached tick is to grasp the tick with fine tweezers close to the skin and then gently pull the tick straight out without twisting motions.

E) INCORRECT:

Ticks should not be removed with matches or flames. The flame may burn the skin.

questions.text:
A 13-year-old girl presents with sudden onset of weakness and subtle paresthesias. Yesterday, she was hiking in the woods with her family and felt fine on her return in the evening. This morning, she woke with tingling in all of her fingers, followed by generalized fatigue and weakness in her arms and legs this afternoon. She has had no recent illnesses or fevers, and her vital signs are normal.
She reports double vision on testing of her extraocular movements, and at times, her speech is difficult to understand. She has 4/5 strength throughout on confrontational testing, diminished reflexes in the arms, and a normal sensory examination. Careful inspection of her skin reveals an engorged tick latched to her upper back.
After removal of the insect, what is the most appropriate next step for this patient?

choices.text: MRI of the spine and neurosurgical consultation
Lumbar puncture followed by intravenous immunoglobulin infusion

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Tick paralysis is the most likely diagnosis in this case, given the onset of dysarthria, diplopia, subjective sensory symptoms, motor weakness, and depressed reflexes, all of which began shortly after a hike in the woods, and the presence of an embedded tick on physical examination.

Tick paralysis is characterized by acute, ascending weakness and ataxia in the setting of tick exposure. Symptoms may progress rapidly, within 24 to 48 hours of exposure to the neurotoxic saliva of the tick, and can involve respiratory and bulbar muscles. In North America, the most commonly implicated tick species are the Rocky Mountain wood tick and the American dog tick. Tick paralysis has an excellent prognosis if diagnosed early. In most cases, there is complete recovery with tick removal and supportive care. Close observation is recommended, as symptoms may initially worsen for up to 24 hours before gradually improving and resolving within 1 to 2 days.

Tick paralysis must be considered in all children presenting with acute ascending weakness. Most cases are easily identified once the tick is encountered. It is not uncommon for a tick to be embedded in the scalp, so a diligent search through the hair and scalp as well as the rest of the body is indicated. If a tick is not discovered on examination, then evaluation of the patient should focus on ruling out other conditions in the differential diagnosis, including Guillain-Barré syndrome, transverse myelitis, botulism, poliomyelitis, West Nile virus infection, myasthenia gravis, and spinal cord compression.

Key learning point: For a patient with paralysis and tick attachment, appropriate treatment includes tick removal and supportive care.

B) INCORRECT:

A spinal cord lesion, such as an infection or malignancy, would typically manifest with increased reflexes and, in some cases, a sensory level. This patient has depressed reflexes and therefore does not require an MRI or neurosurgical evaluation.

C) INCORRECT:

Tick paralysis, which is the most likely diagnosis in this case, is a neurotoxic phenomenon, not an infection, so antibiotics would not be helpful.

D) INCORRECT:

Guillain-Barré syndrome (GBS) should be considered in any child presenting with acute ascending weakness. However, the lack of objective sensory deficits (frequently seen in GBS) and the presence of a tick in this patient make GBS less likely; intravenous immunoglobulin is therefore not indicated. Furthermore, although a lumbar puncture can help differentiate between GBS and tick paralysis (albuminocytologic dissociation [elevated protein but normal leukocyte count] is expected in GBS but not tick paralysis), it may not be useful in this case because the patient has had symptoms for only one day and the cerebrospinal fluid abnormality in GBS is frequently not seen in the first week of symptoms.

E) INCORRECT:

Myasthenia gravis should be considered in patients who present with new onset of weakness, but the absence of facial weakness and presence of a tick in this case makes this diagnosis less likely. Pyridostigmine is therefore not an appropriate treatment for this patient.

questions.text:
A 13-year-old girl presents to the emergency department after an episode of syncope at school. She has had no fevers, cough, congestion, vomiting, or diarrhea. She reports no sick contacts and has no family history of sudden cardiac death or early coronary artery disease. She has been eating and drinking normally and has been healthy overall except for a flulike illness with a rash a few months ago, after she returned from a monthlong summer camp in Wisconsin. She recovered from that illness uneventfully but notes that the rash persisted for about 3 weeks. She describes it as a circular red rash with central clearing on the back of her left calf.
On physical examination, she has a heart rate of 67 beats per minute, a blood pressure of 110/76 mm Hg, and an oxygen saturation of 99% while breathing ambient air. There is no increased work of breathing, and the lung fields are clear to auscultation. Cardiac examination reveals no murmur, rub, or gallop. The abdomen is soft, and the liver is palpable at the right costal margin. The extremities are normal with no evidence of edema. Skin examination reveals some discoloration on the back of the left calf.
An electrocardiogram (figure) shows a heart rate of 71 beats per minute, a PR interval of 326 msec, a QRS duration of 98 msec, and a corrected QT interval of 425 msec.
What is the most appropriate next step in care for this patient?

choices.text: Discharge home with a prescription for oral doxycycline
Administer atropine, and continue on a cardiac monitor in the office
Admit to the hospital for cardiac monitoring, and treat with intravenous ceftriaxone
Discharge home with a wearable cardiac monitor
Admit to the hospital for monitoring, and treat with oral amoxicillin

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

This patient should be hospitalized, monitored, and given intravenous (IV) antibiotics. Discharging her home now with an oral antibiotic would be dangerous, given the possibility of disease progression.

B) INCORRECT:

Administering atropine would be inappropriate. Although this patient has first-degree heart block, she does not have bradycardia.

C) CORRECT:

This patient’s electrocardiogram (ECG) shows significant first-degree heart block with a PR interval of approximately 326 msec (a normal PR interval for a 13-year-old child is 90 to 180 msec). The P axis is slightly negative in lead I, a normal variant that represents a low sinus rhythm. Overall, the patient’s syncopal episode and evidence of significant first-degree heart block in the setting of recent probable tick exposure and erythema migrans is consistent with a diagnosis of Lyme carditis.

Lyme disease has three stages:

The early localized stage usually occurs within a few days to one month after the tick bite. During this stage, the patient often has the typical erythema migrans rash and may have an influenza-like illness.

• The early disseminated stage usually occurs weeks to months after erythema migrans appears, although many patients still have the rash as this stage begins. If there are cardiac abnormalities, they typically surface during this stage, predominantly affecting the conduction system. Patients with Lyme carditis can either be asymptomatic or present with lightheadedness, syncope, dyspnea, palpitations, and/or chest pain. The most common manifestation is self-limited conduction derangement, with largely varying degrees of heart block that can progress rapidly.
• The late persistent stage can manifest with arthritis, fatigue, and difficulties with mood, sleep, and/or speaking.

Patients with Lyme disease who have minor cardiac involvement (PR interval ≤300 msec) and no other symptoms can be treated with early oral antibiotic therapy, typically amoxicillin or doxycycline for 14 to 21 days. If a patient has symptoms or more-significant cardiac involvement (PR interval >300 msec; second- or third-degree heart block), they should be hospitalized and placed on telemetry monitoring given the potential risk for progression of heart block. They should also receive intravenous antibiotics (ceftriaxone, cefotaxime, or high-dose penicillin G) for 14 to 28 days. An estimated one-third of patients require cardiac pacing, but it is usually temporary. Patients typically recover within one week, even those with high-degree heart block, and permanent pacing is usually not needed.

Key learning point: The most appropriate care for a patient with Lyme carditis who has significant first-degree heart block is admission to the hospital for monitoring and for treatment with intravenous antibiotics.

D) INCORRECT:

This patient should be hospitalized, monitored, and given intravenous (IV) antibiotics. Discharging her home now with a wearable cardiac monitor would be dangerous, given the possibility of disease progression.

E) INCORRECT:

Admitting this patient and treating her with an oral rather than an IV antibiotic would be inappropriate, as IV therapy is favored in this setting.

questions.text: A 29-year-old man comes to the office because of a 3-day history of a swollen right knee. Over the past 6 weeks, he has had painful episodes affecting the right knee and the left elbow. He previously had a rash, which subsided 2 months ago. He lives in Connecticut and works as a landscaper. He is sexually active with one female partner and uses condoms consistently. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows a tender and warm right knee; range of motion is limited by pain. Arthrocentesis of the right knee is performed and the synovial fluid appears cloudy. Gram stain is negative. Analysis of the synovial fluid shows a leukocyte count of 27,000/mm3 and 80% neutrophils. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Lyme disease often manifests with a localized rash (i.e., erythema chronicum migrans) and can ultimately lead to systemic infection involving the joints, skin, and central nervous system. The incidence of Lyme disease is highest in the Northeast and upper Midwest of the US and outdoor workers (e.g., rangers, landscapers, farmers) are at an increased risk of infection. Patients may initially have arthralgia or myalgia as a part of the flu-like symptoms of stage I disease. Stage II disease can manifest with migratory arthralgia, which can progress to Lyme arthritis (i.e., stage III; late Lyme disease) if left untreated. Arthrocentesis findings in patients with Lyme arthritis typically include yellow cloudy fluid, leukocytosis with neutrophilic predominance, the absence of crystals, and a negative Gram stain and culture; however, these findings are nonspecific. This patient's presentation of arthritis of the knee, preceded by several weeks of migratory arthralgia, in combination with the arthrocentesis findings is consistent with Lyme arthritis.

Two-step serological testing is indicated to confirm the exposure: An ELISA test should be used as a screening test followed by a Western blot to detect IgG and IgM antibodies against Borrelia burgdorferi. PCR testing of the synovial fluid can be used to confirm the diagnosis in patients with suspected Lyme arthritis who are IgG immunoblot-positive.

B) INCORRECT:

Osteoarthritis commonly affects the knees. However, pain associated with osteoarthritis is isolated to the affected joints and typically worsens toward the end of the day and/or following physical activity, as opposed to the episodic, migratory course seen in this patient. Osteoarthritis also most commonly affects individuals > 65 years of age. Furthermore, this patient's arthrocentesis findings indicate a different process.

C) INCORRECT:

Rheumatoid arthritis is characterized by symmetrical joint involvement (especially of the MCP and PIP joints) rather than migratory arthralgia, as seen in this patient. Other characteristic findings in rheumatoid arthritis include morning stiffness (> 30 minutes), joint deformities (e.g., swan neck deformities, boutonniere deformities, ulnar deviation), and extraarticular manifestations (e.g., constitutional symptoms), none of which are seen here.

D) INCORRECT:

Gonococcal arthritis is caused by Neisseria gonorrhea, the most common cause of septic arthritis in sexually active young adults. Common manifestations of gonococcal arthritis include fever, chills, progressive rash, migratory polyarthralgia, and/or tenosynovitis. In addition, isolated purulent gonococcal arthritis typically manifests as monoarthritis (e.g., of the knee), as seen here, or asymmetric oligoarthritis. Gram staining is often negative and more than half of cases have a negative synovial fluid culture. However, leukocyte count is typically > 50,000/mm3 in gonococcal arthritis. In addition, this patient's geographical location and outdoor occupation make another etiology more likely.

E) INCORRECT:

Reactive arthritis is an immune-mediated condition most commonly caused by bacterial infection of the gastrointestinal or urinary tract. Clinical features include arthritis, which is often asymmetrical and migratory, as seen here. In addition, arthrocentesis findings typically include neutrophilic leukocytosis with a negative Gram stain. However, other characteristic features of reactive arthritis, such as conjunctivitis and urethritis, are not present in this patient. In addition, there is no history of recent gastrointestinal or urinary tract infection.
questions.hint: This patient has progressed to stage III of the illness.

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of dyspnea and palpitations with mild exertion. The patient returned from a summer camping trip in Vermont 6 weeks ago. She had fever, chills, and a circular rash on her arm shortly after the camping trip, which have since resolved. She has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. Vital signs are within normal limits. Electrocardiography shows a second-degree AV block Mobitz type I. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

In a young patient with cardiac symptoms (e.g., palpitations, dyspnea), AV block, or other cardiac arrhythmias a few weeks to months after a possible infection with Borrelia burgdorferi, there should be a high level of suspicion for Lyme carditis. Cardiac manifestations are a feature of early disseminated Lyme disease, which typically occurs 3–10 weeks after a tick bite. Intravenous ceftriaxone is the first-line treatment for adults and children with severe Lyme carditis (i.e., symptomatic patients, first-degree AV block with PR interval ≥ 300 ms, second- or third-degree AV block). Other severe manifestations of Lyme disease that warrant hospitalization and intravenous antibiotic therapy include encephalopathy, polyneuropathy, and persistent arthritis. Less severe manifestations of Lyme disease (e.g., mild carditis, isolated cranial nerve palsy, migratory arthralgias) should be treated with oral doxycycline (or amoxicillin in patients who are pregnant or lactating).

Lyme disease is diagnosed with two-step serological testing (ELISA followed by Western blot).

B) INCORRECT:

Oral amoxicillin is the first-line treatment for pregnant or lactating patients with Lyme disease who do not require hospitalization, such as those with mild carditis (i.e., first-degree AV block with PR interval < 300 ms). In patients with more severe manifestations of Lyme disease, another form of therapy is indicated.

C) INCORRECT:

As beta blockers have negative inotropic, dromotropic, and chronotropic effects, which typically lead to decreased blood pressure and decreased oxygen consumption by the heart, they can be used to treat hypertension and heart failure. Beta-blocker therapy is contraindicated in patients with AV block.

D) INCORRECT:

Oral doxycycline is the first-line treatment for most patients with Lyme disease who do not require hospitalization, such as those with mild carditis (i.e., first-degree AV block with PR interval < 300 ms). In patients with more severe manifestations of Lyme disease, another form of therapy is indicated.

E) INCORRECT:

Permanent pacemaker implantation is not usually necessary to treat an AV block caused by Lyme carditis. Temporary pacemaker implantation may be required, however, in severe cases (e.g., second-degree AV block Mobitz type II or third-degree AV block) or in patients who are hemodynamically unstable.
questions.hint: Although no tick bite has been reported, an episode of flu-like symptoms and a circular rash (erythema migrans) shortly after a camping trip to an endemic area (Northeast and Upper Midwest of the US) should raise concern for Lyme disease.

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman reports a one-week history of worsening swelling, stiffness, and pain in her right knee. She denies fevers, chills, and neurologic symptoms. She is afebrile and has normal vital signs. Her right knee has a moderate effusion without significant erythema. Flexing the knee causes her some pain. Her neurologic examination is normal. The patient recalls developing an erythematous circular rash after a tick bite several months ago. Fluid from an arthrocentesis reveals a leukocyte count of 25,000 per mm3 and a negative Gram stain. A culture is negative at 72 hours. Which one of the following antibiotic regimens is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Lyme-associated arthritis can be a manifestation of early disseminated disease but is often associated with late disseminated disease months to years after initial infection. It may be monoarticular or oligoarticular, intermittent or chronic, and most commonly affects the knees. The diagnosis of Lyme arthritis is supported by the presence of positive Lyme-disease serology testing, supporting history and symptoms, and the absence of a positive culture from synovial fluid.

The first-line treatment for Lyme arthritis is oral doxycycline, amoxicillin, or cefuroxime axetil for 28 days. A second round of antibiotics is appropriate for patients with symptoms that persist despite treatment. In some cases, arthritis remains as a permanent sequela and is managed supportively.

Key learning point: The most appropriate first-line antibiotic therapy for Lyme-associated arthritis is doxycycline, amoxicillin, or cefuroxime axetil for 28 days.
Image Description:

A large, primary lesion with circular erythema and central clearing on the posterior side of the right upper arm is visible.

This clinical picture is typical of erythema migrans (stage-I Lyme disease).

Illustration: Bull's eye sign

B) INCORRECT:

Fluoroquinolones, such as moxifloxacin, are not recommended for treating Lyme disease.

C) INCORRECT:

Cephalexin is not active against Lyme disease.

D) INCORRECT:

Parenteral therapy with ceftriaxone is reserved for Lyme-associated arthritis that does not respond to oral therapy. Prolonged therapy with intravenous ceftriaxone is not indicated.

E) INCORRECT:

In early Lyme disease, azithromycin is inferior to amoxicillin and is not routinely recommended for Lyme arthritis.
questions.hint: Patients with Lyme-associated arthritis typically present with a culture-negative inflammatory arthritis. There may also be a history of a known tick bite, a recent circular rash (erythema migrans), or both, as seen in this patient.

questions.text: A 31-year-old woman, gravida 1, para 0, at 10 weeks' gestation comes to the office because of a rash on her upper arm that appeared 3 days ago. She has also had headaches and muscle aches for 1 day. She went on a camping trip in Maine 10 days ago. Her temperature is 39°C (102.2°F). A photograph of her rash is shown. Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Levofloxacin is a fluoroquinolone, which is absolutely contraindicated in pregnant women because of the risk of fetal cartilage damage. Moreover, most fluoroquinolones are typically ineffective against spirochetes.

B) INCORRECT:

Azoles (e.g., clotrimazole) are used to treat fungal infections such as tinea corporis. Tinea corporis can manifest as an annular erythematous rash with a central clearing but the rash would have a scaly border and is not associated with systemic symptoms (e.g., headache, myalgias). This patient most likely has a bacterial infection and ergosterol is not a bacterial component.
Image Description:

An erythematous patch with mild scaling and central clearing is seen on the left wrist.

These features are characteristic of dermatophyte fungal infection.

C) INCORRECT:

Isoniazid is an antituberculous drug that prevents cell wall synthesis by inhibiting the synthesis of mycolic acid. Mycolic acid is present in Mycobacteria spp. but absent in spirochetes.

D) INCORRECT:

Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole is typically ineffective against spirochetes. Moreover, sulfonamide antibiotics are absolutely contraindicated in pregnant women because of the risk of kernicterus in the newborn.

E) CORRECT:

Doxycycline is the first-line treatment for Lyme disease but is relatively contraindicated in pregnant and nursing women because of its adverse effects on the growing bones and teeth of the fetus or newborn (doxycycline is safer than older tetracyclines, which are absolutely contraindicated in pregnant and nursing women). Certain penicillin antibiotics (e.g., amoxicillin, penicillin G) and certain cephalosporins of the second generation (e.g., cefuroxime axetil) or third generation (e.g., ceftriaxone) are used to treat Lyme disease in pregnant or nursing women.
questions.hint: This patient's rash is consistent with erythema migrans, which is pathognomonic for early localized Lyme disease. The pathogen responsible for Lyme disease is the spirochete Borrelia burgdorferi.

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman comes to the office because of a 4-day history of swelling and pain in her left knee. She has had similar episodes of swollen joints over the past 3 weeks. Two months ago, she had a rash on her upper back that subsided after a few days. She lives in Pennsylvania and works as a forest ranger. Her temperature is 37.8°C (100°F). Physical examination shows a tender and warm left knee. Arthrocentesis of the knee joint yields cloudy fluid with a leukocyte count of 30,000/mm3 and 80% neutrophils. A Gram stain of synovial fluid does not show any organisms. Which of the following is the most likely causal organism?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:
