Pseudomonas aeruginosa is a common cause of septic arthritis in immunodeficient patients. Septic arthritis may manifest with a tender and swollen knee and low-grade fever. However, septic arthritis typically involves infection of a single joint (monoarthritis) and is characterized by an acute onset and course. A rash would also not be expected before the onset of arthritis. Moreover, arthrocentesis would show an elevated WBC count and Gram staining would show gram-negative bacilli. Finally, this patient has no history of conditions that would increase the risk of P. aeruginosa infection (e.g., malignancy, HIV infection, diabetes mellitus).

B) INCORRECT:

Infection with Staphylococcus aureus, the most common cause of septic arthritis, would manifest with inflammation of the knee joint and elevated body temperature. However, septic arthritis typically involves infection of a single joint (monoarthritis) and is characterized by an acute onset and course. A rash would also not be expected before the onset of arthritis. Moreover, arthrocentesis would show a yellowish-green, turbid fluid with an elevated WBC count (neutrophil predominant), and Gram staining would show gram-positive cocci. Finally, the fact that this patient lives in the Northeast and works outdoors makes another type of infection more likely.

C) INCORRECT:

Reactive arthritis due to Campylobacter jejuni infection can manifest with inflammation of several joints (polyarthritis), a skin lesion, and elevated body temperature. Additionally, synovial fluid would not show any organisms and would typically show a mildly elevated WBC count (< 40,000/mm3). However, the skin lesion would typically be located on the glans (balanitis circinata) or present as a hyperkeratinization of the palms and soles (keratoderma blenorrhagicum), but a rash would not be expected on the trunk. Reactive arthritis is also usually preceded by a gastrointestinal or urogenital infection. Furthermore, the fact that this patient lives in the Northeast and works outdoors makes another type of infection more likely.

D) INCORRECT:

Infection with Neisseria gonorrhoeae, the causative pathogen of gonococcal arthritis, is the most common form of arthritis resulting from a disseminated genitourinary tract infection in sexually active young adults. Gonococcal arthritis can manifest with inflammation of several joints (polyarthralgia), an elevated body temperature, a rash on the trunk, and arthrocentesis showing a cloudy fluid with an increased WBC count. However, Gram staining would show gram-negative diplococci, and the fact that this patient lives in the Northeast and works outdoors makes another type of infection more likely.

E) CORRECT:

Borrelia burgdorferi is a tick-borne spiral-shaped bacteria that causes Lyme disease, which typically begins with a localized rash (i.e., erythema chronicum migrans) and ultimately can cause systemic infection involving the joints, skin, and central nervous system. The incidence of Lyme disease is highest in the Northeast and upper Midwest of the US, and outdoor workers (e.g., rangers, landscapers, farmers) are at an increased risk of infection. The nonspecific arthrocentesis findings, i.e., no organisms on Gram stain and leukocytosis with increased neutrophils are consistent with Lyme arthritis. Two-step serological testing is indicated to confirm exposure: The screening test ELISA should be followed by a Western blot test to detect IgG and IgM antibodies against Borrelia. However, positive results only demonstrate exposure to Borrelia, not necessarily current infection. PCR (arthrocentesis) is best for confirming suspected Lyme arthritis in patients who are IgG immunoblot-positive. The treatment for Lyme arthritis in adults is oral doxycycline.

Key learning point: Lyme arthritis is caused by Borrelia burgdorferi, a tick-borne spirochete endemic to the Northeast and upper Midwest United States.
questions.hint: This patient has progressed to stage III of the illness.

Image Description:

A large, primary lesion with circular erythema and central clearing on the posterior side of the right upper arm is visible.

This clinical picture is typical of erythema migrans (stage-I Lyme disease).

Illustration: Bull's eye sign

C) INCORRECT:

In early Lyme disease, azithromycin is inferior to amoxicillin and is not routinely recommended for Lyme arthritis.

D) INCORRECT:

Fluoroquinolones, such as moxifloxacin, are not recommended for treating Lyme disease.

E) INCORRECT:

Parenteral therapy with ceftriaxone is reserved for Lyme-associated arthritis that does not respond to oral therapy. Prolonged therapy with intravenous ceftriaxone is not indicated.

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman comes to your clinic with a 4-day history of swelling and pain in her left knee. She reports having had similar episodes of swollen joints over the past 3 weeks. Two months ago, she had a rash on her upper back that resolved after a few days. She lives in Nova Scotia and works as a forest ranger. Her temperature is 37.8°C. On examination, her left knee is tender and warm. Arthrocentesis yields cloudy synovial fluid with a leukocyte count of 30 × 109/L and 80% neutrophils. Gram stain of the synovial fluid does not show any organisms. Which one of the following is the most likely causal organism?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Pseudomonas aeruginosa is a common cause of septic arthritis in immunodeficient patients. Septic arthritis may manifest with a tender and swollen knee and low-grade fever. However, septic arthritis typically involves infection of a single joint (monoarthritis) and is characterized by an acute onset and course. A rash would also not be expected before the onset of arthritis. Moreover, arthrocentesis would show an elevated WBC count and Gram staining would show gram-negative bacilli. Finally, this patient has no history of conditions that would increase the risk of P. aeruginosa infection (e.g., malignancy, HIV infection, diabetes mellitus).

Infection with Staphylococcus aureus, the most common cause of septic arthritis, would manifest with inflammation of the knee joint and elevated body temperature. However, septic arthritis typically involves infection of a single joint (monoarthritis) and is characterized by an acute onset and course. A rash would also not be expected before the onset of arthritis. Moreover, arthrocentesis would show a yellowish-green, turbid fluid with an elevated WBC count (neutrophil predominant), and Gram staining would show gram-positive cocci. Finally, the fact that this patient lives in the Northeast and works outdoors makes another type of infection more likely.

C) INCORRECT:

Reactive arthritis due to Campylobacter jejuni infection can manifest with inflammation of several joints (polyarthritis), a skin lesion, and elevated body temperature. Additionally, synovial fluid would not show any organisms and would typically show a mildly elevated WBC count (< 40 × 109/L). However, the skin lesion would typically be located on the glans (balanitis circinata) or present as a hyperkeratinization of the palms and soles (keratoderma blenorrhagicum), but a rash would not be expected on the trunk. Reactive arthritis is also usually preceded by a gastrointestinal or urogenital infection. Furthermore, the fact that this patient lives in the Northeast and works outdoors makes another type of infection more likely.

D) INCORRECT:

Infection with Neisseria gonorrhoeae, the causative pathogen of gonococcal arthritis, is the most common form of arthritis resulting from a disseminated genitourinary tract infection in sexually active young adults. Gonococcal arthritis can manifest with inflammation of several joints (polyarthralgia), an elevated body temperature, a rash on the trunk, and arthrocentesis showing a cloudy fluid with an increased WBC count. However, Gram staining would show gram-negative diplococci, and the fact that this patient lives in the Northeast and works outdoors makes another type of infection more likely.

E) CORRECT:

Borrelia burgdorferi is a tick-borne spiral-shaped bacterium that causes Lyme disease, which typically begins with a localized rash (i.e., erythema chronicum migrans) and ultimately can cause systemic infection involving the joints, skin, and central nervous system. In Canada, endemic areas include the Atlantic provinces (Nova Scotia, parts of New Brunswick), the Great Lakes–St. Lawrence region (southern Ontario, Québec), the southern Prairies (Manitoba, western Ontario), and the Pacific coast region (coastal British Columbia, Vancouver Island). Outdoor workers (park/forest rangers, landscapers, farmers) are at higher risk. The nonspecific arthrocentesis findings, i.e., no organisms on Gram stain and leukocytosis with increased neutrophils, are consistent with Lyme arthritis. Two-step serological testing is indicated to confirm exposure: The screening test ELISA should be followed by a Western blot test to detect IgG and IgM antibodies against Borrelia. However, positive results only demonstrate exposure to Borrelia, not necessarily current infection. PCR (arthrocentesis) is best for confirming suspected Lyme arthritis in patients who are IgG immunoblot-positive. The treatment for Lyme arthritis in adults is oral doxycycline.

Key learning point: Lyme arthritis is caused by Borrelia burgdorferi, a tick-borne spirochete.
questions.hint: This patient has progressed to stage III of the illness.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents with a 4-day history of an expanding rash on her right arm. She went hiking in wooded areas of New Hampshire 10 days ago but does not recall a tick bite. The lesion started as a small red spot and has progressively enlarged. A warm, nontender rash (as shown) is noted on physical examination. There is no fever, headache, or joint pain. What is the most appropriate next step?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Lyme serology is not indicated for patients with typical erythema migrans. This characteristic clinical appearance allows for confident diagnosis, and serological testing would delay appropriate treatment. Furthermore, early Lyme disease often has negative serology due to insufficient time for antibody development.

B) CORRECT:

Correct -- This patient has typical erythema migrans based on the expanding erythematous ring with central clearing that developed 7–14 days after potential tick exposure in an endemic area. Erythema migrans is pathognomonic for early localized Lyme disease and requires immediate antibiotic treatment. Doxycycline is the first-line oral antibiotic for Lyme disease.

C) INCORRECT:

Skin biopsy is not necessary for typical erythema migrans and would unnecessarily delay treatment while providing no additional diagnostic value for this pathognomonic finding.

D) INCORRECT:

Intravenous ceftriaxone is reserved for complicated Lyme disease (e.g., neuroborreliosis with central nervous system involvement, severe carditis). This patient has uncomplicated early localized disease.

E) INCORRECT:

Azithromycin is considered an alternative agent for erythema migrans and is typically reserved for patients with contraindications to both doxycycline and beta-lactam antibiotics.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents with a 4-day history of left facial weakness and inability to close her left eye completely. Three weeks ago, she developed intermittent joint pain involving multiple joints that seems to move from one joint to another. She spent a weekend camping in Vermont approximately 8 weeks ago and recalls feeling unwell for several days afterward with fever and fatigue. Physical examination shows left facial droop with forehead involvement and inability to raise the left eyebrow. Cardiac examination shows bradycardia with a heart rate of 48/minute. ECG shows a PR interval of 340 ms with occasional dropped beats. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Anticoagulation is not indicated for disseminated Lyme disease. The bradycardia and conduction abnormalities are likely due to inflammatory carditis rather than thrombotic disease.

B) INCORRECT:

Corticosteroids are the mainstay of treatment for idiopathic Bell palsy. Cardiac conduction abnormalities and migratory arthralgia following outdoor exposure in an endemic area suggest a systemic disease process.

C) INCORRECT:

Cardiac catheterization is not indicated for atrioventricular block in patients with suspected infectious carditis.

D) INCORRECT:

Lumbar puncture is not routinely recommended for neuroborreliosis and is not the most appropriate next step for this patient. The clinical presentation suggests peripheral cranial neuropathy rather than central nervous system involvement, and confirmatory serological testing should be obtained first.

E) CORRECT:

Correct -- The combination of unilateral facial palsy, high-degree atrioventricular block with markedly prolonged PR interval, and migratory arthralgia occurring weeks after outdoor exposure in an endemic area strongly suggests early disseminated Lyme disease. Lyme serology is the appropriate initial diagnostic test to confirm the diagnosis before initiating antibiotic therapy.

questions.text: A 42-year-old man presents with a 6-week history of right knee pain and swelling. He reports brief episodes of joint pain in his wrists and ankles over the past 8 months that resolved spontaneously. He works as a landscaper in Massachusetts. Physical examination shows a large knee effusion with warmth and decreased range of motion. Vital signs are normal. Laboratory studies show normal erythrocyte sedimentation rate, normal CBC, and normal C-reactive protein. Arthrocentesis yields cloudy yellow fluid with leukocyte count 22,000/mm3 (58% neutrophils), glucose within normal range, negative Gram stain, and negative bacterial culture. What is the most appropriate next diagnostic step?

choices.text: Synovial fluid polymerase chain reaction for Borrelia burgdorferi

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Crystal analysis is appropriate for crystalline arthropathy. This patient's demographics, occupational exposure, and pattern of joint involvement make Lyme arthritis the primary consideration rather than gout or pseudogout.

B) CORRECT:

Correct -- The combination of monoarthritis affecting a large joint, a history of migratory arthralgia, endemic geographic location, and characteristic synovial fluid findings strongly suggests Lyme arthritis.

C) INCORRECT:

Synovial fluid polymerase chain reaction for Borrelia burgdorferi has low sensitivity and is not routinely recommended for the initial diagnosis of Lyme arthritis, which is typically established with clinical presentation and positive serology.

D) INCORRECT:

Serum uric acid levels are appropriate for suspected gout. This patient's age, pattern of intermittent large joint involvement, and geographic location make Lyme arthritis more likely than crystal arthropathy.

E) INCORRECT:

Antinuclear antibody testing is considered for autoimmune arthritis. This patient's pattern of asymmetric monoarthritis with prior migratory symptoms in an endemic area is more consistent with infectious arthritis than systemic autoimmune disease.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman presents with a 5-day history of right facial weakness and an inability to close her right eye completely. She went hiking in a wooded area of Vermont 5 weeks ago and recalls finding a tick on her leg, which she removed. She denies fever, headache, neck stiffness, or rash. Physical examination shows complete right facial nerve palsy with forehead involvement but no other neurological deficits. Vital signs are normal. Lyme serology is positive. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Vancomycin is not indicated for Lyme disease treatment. This antibiotic is primarily used for gram-positive bacterial infections, particularly methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus.

B) CORRECT:

Correct -- Oral doxycycline is the preferred first-line treatment for isolated cranial nerve palsy in neuroborreliosis.

C) INCORRECT:

Azithromycin is not recommended as first-line therapy for neurological manifestations of Lyme disease. An alternative agent is more appropriate.

D) INCORRECT:

Although it may be considered for treatment of bacterial meningitis, ampicillin is not a first-line agent for treatment of neuroborreliosis. An alternative agent is more appropriate.

E) INCORRECT:

Corticosteroids alone do not treat the underlying Borrelia infection and are not indicated as primary therapy for Lyme neuroborreliosis.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents to the emergency department 30 hours after removing an embedded tick from her leg during a hiking trip in Vermont. She discovered the tick while showering and believes it was not present when she showered the previous evening, although she is uncertain of the exact attachment time. The tick was moderately engorged and has been identified as Ixodes scapularis. The bite site shows mild erythema without a characteristic rash. She reports no fever, headache, or other symptoms. What is the most appropriate management?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Correct -- This patient meets all the criteria for postexposure prophylaxis. The tick was identified as Ixodes scapularis, occurred in a highly endemic area (Vermont), was likely attached for ≥ 36 hours based on moderate engorgement, and prophylaxis is being initiated within 72 hours of removal. The recommended prophylactic regimen is a single dose of oral doxycycline.

B) INCORRECT:

Amoxicillin is an alternative treatment option for established Lyme disease; it is not the recommended agent for postexposure prophylaxis.

C) INCORRECT:

Observation alone is inappropriate if all criteria for prophylaxis are met. This patient has appropriate species identification, endemic area exposure, likely adequate attachment time, and is within the treatment window for effective prophylaxis.

D) INCORRECT:

Empiric treatment with a full course of doxycycline is used for established Lyme disease, not prophylaxis. This patient has no clinical evidence of infection and meets criteria for single-dose prophylaxis rather than therapeutic treatment.

E) INCORRECT:

Lyme serology is not recommended for postexposure prophylaxis. Serology has poor sensitivity in early disease and is used for diagnosing established infection in patients with compatible clinical presentations.

questions.text: A 22-year-old man presents to the clinic with a 2-day history of right-sided facial weakness. He reports difficulty closing his right eye and an asymmetric smile. Three weeks ago, he went on a camping trip in rural Connecticut. He has also been experiencing intermittent headaches, fatigue, and migratory joint pain in his knees and elbows for the past week. He denies any rash. His temperature is 37.9°C (100.2°F). Physical examination shows unilateral paralysis of the entire right side of his face, including the forehead. The remainder of the neurologic examination is unremarkable. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial test to evaluate for the suspected underlying cause?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A Western blot is a crucial part of the diagnostic algorithm for Lyme disease, but it is not the appropriate initial test. It is the second, confirmatory step performed only after a positive or equivocal result on a screening test because it is less sensitive and can lead to false-negative results if used first.

B) INCORRECT:

CT of the head is used to evaluate for structural causes of facial weakness, such as a stroke, tumor, or abscess. However, this patient's paralysis of the entire right side of the face, including the forehead, is characteristic of a peripheral (lower motor neuron) nerve palsy. This finding, along with his age and constellation of systemic symptoms, makes an infectious cause like Lyme disease much more likely than a central structural lesion.

C) INCORRECT:

A lumbar puncture would be indicated to evaluate for other signs of neuroborreliosis, such as meningitis. However, in a patient with an isolated facial nerve palsy without other neurologic signs or symptoms suggestive of CNS involvement, serologic testing is the appropriate initial step. A lumbar puncture is more invasive and not the first-line test for this patient.

D) INCORRECT:

While PCR can detect bacterial DNA, its utility in diagnosing Lyme disease from a blood sample is limited. The spirochetes that cause Lyme disease are primarily tissue-based and are rarely present in the bloodstream in sufficient quantities for reliable detection, leading to a very low sensitivity. PCR is more useful on synovial fluid in cases of Lyme arthritis or on cerebrospinal fluid in suspected neuroborreliosis, but it is not the recommended initial test for this patient's presentation.

E) CORRECT:

The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention recommends a two-tiered serologic testing approach to the diagnosis of Lyme disease. The initial test is a sensitive screening assay, most commonly an enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA), which detects antibodies to Borrelia burgdorferi. If the ELISA is positive or equivocal, it is followed by a more specific confirmatory Western blot. Antibodies typically appear 2–4 weeks after the initial infection, which aligns with this patient's timeline. Unilateral or bilateral facial nerve palsy is the most common cranial neuropathy in Lyme disease.
questions.hint: This patient's presentation of unilateral facial nerve palsy, migratory arthralgias, fatigue, and headache following a camping trip in an endemic area is highly suggestive of early disseminated Lyme disease.
